column1: Aliso Viejo is a city in the San Joaquin Hills of southern Orange County
column2: California. It had a population of 47
column5: 166 as of the 2000 census. It became Orange County's 34th city on July 1
column7: the only city in Orange County to be incorporated since 2000. It is bordered by the cities of Laguna Beach on the west and southwest
column10: and Laguna Woods on the north.

It was the first community-wide association of its kind in California and has the unique ability to provide a full-range of community services and facilities.Aliso Viejo was the first planned community in California to plan a balance between the projected resident work force and the number of projected jobs within its borders. column1: Aliso Viejo had been an unincorporated community since 1979
column2: and incorporated as a city in 2001 due to the efforts of the Aliso Viejo Cityhood 2000 Committee
column3: which was responsible for introducing an initiative on the ballot for the 2001 special election. Voters passed the initiative with 93.3% in favor of incorporation. Carmen Vali-Cave
column4: the co-founder and president of the committee
column5: became the new city's first mayor.

Aliso Viejo is a general law city with a council-manager system of government. Day-to-day operations are handled by a professional city manager overseen by a volunteer city council. The City Council of Aliso Viejo consists of five members serving staggered four-year terms. Each year
column2: the Council votes for its next Mayor and Mayor pro tem. The current City Council consists of Mayor Mike Munzing
column4: and Council Members David C. Harrington
column5: Ross Chun

column5: and Wood Canyon Creek forms part of the city's western boundary. Much of the city rests on the east slope of the San Joaquin Hills
column6: which are a coastal mountain range extending for about 15 miles (24 km) along the Pacific coast.

column1: The Orange County Gladiators were an American Basketball Association (ABA) expansion team founded in November 2007 until 2009. They played their home games at Aliso Niguel High School.
Aliso Viejo city officials famously came close to banning polystyrene cups in 2004 after hearing that "dihydrogen monoxide" was used in their production
column2: oblivious to the fact that this substance is actually plain water. A paralegal working for the city found the dhmo.org parody website and subsequently proposed the ban.
the city gained national media attention once again when 19-year-old resident William Freund donned a cape and mask

column8: the family of the two victims sued Freund's parents for "wrongful death and emotional distress."

column2: Aliso Viejo residents were protesting the United States Postal Service's plan to build a large mail distribution facility. The proposed facility would have up to 500 employees and USPS trucks traveling over residential streets 24 hours per day. Residents were concerned about damage to city streets
column3: traffic and the trucks traveling through city neighborhoods. On March 9
column5: the USPS announced that it would not move forward with plans to build the distribution facility due to the economic outlook at the time.
